questionListItems.title: When will my doctors act on the wishes in my Advance Care Planning (ACP)? When will it take into effect?

answer.body: The objective of an ACP is to help you have a say in your healthcare if you no longer have mental capacity. As long as you have mental capacity, you will be consulted on your preferences.

questionListItems.title: What are the differences between Advance Care Planning (ACP) & Advance Medical Directive (AMD)?

answer.body:
An Advance Medical Directive (AMD) only covers your preferences for life-sustaining treatment should you become terminally ill and lose your mental capacity. 

However, there are many other aspects that are important for your loved ones and healthcare team to know too. Examples of important healthcare decisions include: pain management options, where you would like to be cared for, and where you would like to spend your last days. These are included as part of the discussion for an Advance Care Plan (ACP).

questionListItems.title: How do I edit my Advance Care Planning (ACP)?

answer.body: To amend the ACP draft, you will need to re-do it using the LPA-ACP tool on My Legacy - https://go.gov.sg/mylegacy-lpa-acp. Alternatively, you can inform the ACP Facilitator of the changes which you want to make to the draft during the facilitation session.

questionListItems.title: Must my Advance Care Planning (ACP) Nominated Healthcare Spokesperson (NHS) be my LPA Donee?

answer.body:
No, you do not have to appoint your LPA Donee with Personal Welfare powers to be your ACP Nominated Healthcare Spokesperson. However, you’re encouraged to do so, to reduce conflicting decisions made by your Donee and NHS.

This is because an LPA grants your Donee the legal rights to make decisions for you if you’re unable to do so, but it does not tell your Donee what to do for your Personal Welfare. 

An ACP helps you to communicate to your Donee what decisions they should make for your Personal Welfare. This includes decisions such as where you should live, who you should live with, your daily lifestyle and healthcare decisions. 

Because of this, appointing your LPA Donee with Personal Welfare powers as your ACP Nominated Healthcare Spokesperson will help to avoid conflicts amongst your loved ones.

questionListItems.title: How to check the deceased's insurance policy as the insurance company will not disclose the information?

answer.body:
You can check with the insurance company on the necessary documentation needed such as a death certificate and proof of your relationship to the deceased, to establish your legitimacy in seeking this information.

If the insurance company continues to refuse your request, you may consider consulting a lawyer who specialises in insurance law. They can help you understand your rights and options and may be able to intervene on your behalf.

questionListItems.title: How do I check if the deceased has any other insurance besides the CPF nomination?

answer.body: You can contact the insurance companies directly to enquire.

questionListItems.title: If the deceased passed on without a will, what will happen to the bank account? Can next-of-kin (NOK) contact the bank directly or the request need to be facilitated by the trustee?

answer.body:
We would like to clarify that unclaimed monies in bank accounts will continue to be held by the banks even when the accounts are inactive or the account holder has passed on.


As the deceased has not made a will, you will need to first obtain the Grant of Letter of Administration from the court, then present the Letter of Administration to each bank in order for banks to disclose the deceased’s account information to you. This is the only legal method to access the deceased’s bank account(s).


You can check the Family Justice Courts website (https://www.judiciary.gov.sg/family/apply-for-letters-of-administration) or enquire with the Family Justice Courts for more information on the court procedure.

questionListItems.title: Inquiry about putting CPF nomination for family members who are not a Singaporean/ Permanent Resident

answer.body:
CPF members can nominate any person in their nominations and this includes non-Singaporeans / Permanent Residents.


CPF members can visit CPF website to find out who they can nominate - https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/who-can-i-include-as-my-nominee.

questionListItems.title: If the deceased passed on without a will and did not make a CPF nomination. Will CPF contact the trustee directly on CPF distribution or do we need to engage administrator/trustee ourselves?

answer.body: If a member did not make a CPF nomination, upon his/her passing, his/her CPF savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office (PTO) for distribution to family members under intestacy laws or inheritance laws (for Muslims). For more information, you can refer to: https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/what-happens-to-my-cpf-savings-if-i-did-not-make-a-cpf-nominatio.

questionListItems.title: If a person nominates the religion organization under their CPF nomination, will CPF inform the organization?

answer.body: Please contact CPF at https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us on your query.

questionListItems.title: How to check the deceased’s CPF nomination?

answer.body: Please contact CPF at https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us on your query.

questionListItems.title: If the deceased passed on, can it be directly proceed to Mandai crematorium to cremate immediately? Do I need to book with NEA? and if there any requirement to buy a coffin?

answer.body: For post-death matters related to cremation and burial, you can refer to https://mylegacy.life.gov.sg/when-death-happens/ under the title “Arrange the funeral” for more information. Alternatively, you can refer to NEA website https://www.nea.gov.sg/our-services/after-death/post-death-matters for more details on the application for Permit to Bury/ Cremate body and other related services.

questionListItems.title: If their godparents who have no next-of-kin passed on next time, how to apply for cremation and permit for ash scattering?

answer.body: For post-death matters related to cremation and ash scattering you can refer to https://www.nea.gov.sg/our-services/after-death/post-death-matters/burial-cremation-and-ash-storage for more information.

questionListItems.title: Inquire about the burial cost is per year or one time cost only?

answer.body: The Choa Chu Kang Cemetery Complex is the only cemetery in Singapore open for burials that is managed by the National Environment Agency (NEA). The burial fee as indicated in NEA website https://www.nea.gov.sg/our-services/after-death/post-death-matters/burial-cremation-and-ash-storage is a once-off payment. The payment of the burial fee for the grave plot is to be made at the service counters before burial. Foreigners are allowed to be buried in Singapore only if the deceased persons have immediate family members who are Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents. More information related to burial can be found at https://www.nea.gov.sg/our-services/after-death/post-death-matters/burial-cremation-and-ash-storage.

questionListItems.title: How to find the approved funeral services providers/undertakers that handles HIV deceased. Is it a must for the deceased to be buried or cremated within 24 hours?

answer.body: The list of approved funeral services providers that could handle HIV deceased can be found in the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) website at https://www.ncid.sg/For-General-Public/Pages/List-of-Funeral-Service-Companies-Trained-in-Basic-Infection-Control-Course-(BICC).aspx There is no requirement for HIV deceased to be buried or cremated within 24 hours.
